My visit to the Saint-Antoine des Quinze Vingts Church in Paris was a truly enriching experience! This Roman Catholic church, located at 66 Avenue Ledru Rollin in the 12th arrondissement of Paris, is a true architectural gem.  The Saint-Antoine des Quinze Vingts Church is built of brick and stone according to a basilical plan in the neo-Romanesque style. Its design is both elegant and imposing, and the interior is equally impressive. I was captivated by the details of the sculptures and stained glass windows, which add a touch of beauty and spirituality to this sacred place.  The atmosphere of the church is one of calm and serenity. Walking through its alleys, I felt a deep inner peace. It is a place where you can gather, meditate and connect to your spirituality.  In addition, the Saint-Antoine des Quinze Vingts Church offers regular religious services. If you have the opportunity to attend a mass, I highly recommend it. It is a unique spiritual experience that will allow you to immerse yourself in the fervor of the local Catholic community.  In conclusion, my visit to the √âglise Saint-Antoine des Quinze Vingts in Paris was a memorable experience. I left with a deep admiration for this place of worship and a feeling of inner peace. üôè‚ú®üòä

Located between avenue Ledru-Rollin and rue Traversi√®re, the church takes its name from two religious establishments in the Faubourg Saint-Antoine, which have now disappeared. First, the Cistercian abbey of Saint-Antoine-des-Champs founded in the 12th century outside the walls of Paris and occupied, from 1795, by the current Saint-Antoine hospital. Then, the hospice for the blind of the Quinze- Twenty ¬†founded by King Saint Louis at the beginning of the 13th century in the Faubourg Saint-Honor√©, then transferred in 1780 in the disused barracks of the Black Musketeers, current site of the National Ophthalmology Hospital Center.  In 1898, thanks to the generosity of the faithful, Father Rivi√®re purchased the current site: a long trapezoidal plot. The architect Lucien Roy (1850-1941) built the church to the plans of √âmile Vaudreme, his master, between 1902 and 1904.
Building with modern details, some very tasteful, some not at all.

The Saint-Antoine parish looks like a manor on the outside with its tower and it is a real gem of modern art on the inside with an astonishing glass dome and ironwork all along. It‚Äôs a place as disconcerting as it is aesthetic! This church has no less than two organs and very pretty statues, notably of Saint Louis and Saint Anthony. The atmosphere is cozy and serene, you feel good there. I discovered this church completely by chance which is located not far from the Gare de Lyon, its location is very discreet, between two buildings. A truly great discovery that I highly recommend.

Superb church. We feel very welcome there! There is a very beautiful community in this parish! What solidarity, what dynamism, what human warmth! The Alpha Course is incredible! Magnificent feast of Saint Anthony where lunch is organized in the church!  Magnificent Laudato Si eco photo exhibition from the end of September to October 9, 2020üëç

It is a church that cannot be seen from the outside because it is hidden by the mass of businesses on the street. On the other hand, seen from the inside, it is very large and above all very high. It houses people who come to worship or chat outside of worship.

Beautiful Church, both modern and Romanesque, very well preserved. There is a beautiful-sounding organ and a Stations of the Cross located on the keystones of the left and right naves, lit by small judiciously placed spotlights. There are two entrances, one on the Ledru Rolin side and the other on the rue Traversi√®re side. Upstairs with stairs and elevator there is a large room that can accommodate around fifty guests. The pastoral team and priests are very available and particularly interesting.
Very beautiful church a stone's throw from Lyon train station. There are two organs in this church, which I had never seen before. Very surprising. It is also well maintained, you feel good there.

Amazing early 20th century church wedged between 2 buildings, very close to the Promenade Plante. Interior in concrete and cement brightened with frescoes and a soft and soothing light coming through the stained glass windows. A soothing atmosphere conducive to meditation and of course prayer (for those who believe).

Charming little church. Sit back to appreciate the two statues of Saint Louis and Saint Anthony which represent a universal dichotomy between the two types of power: force and the sacred. A very mystical atmosphere reigns and the narrowness of the place is absolutely not stuffy

Church a little dark, very beautiful, in the 12th two establishments had the privilege of exercising "soul cure": the abbey of Cistrercian nuns of Saint-Antoine des Champs and the hospice of the 15/20, foundation of Saint Louis.The abbey was abolished in 1790 and the monastery assigned to the Saint-Antoine hospital in 1795. The new parish of Saint-Antoine des Quinze-Vingts was created on February 4, 1791. Very friendly parish team.
Magnificent church. Who would have thought to find such beauty, both spiritual and architectural, in this street in Paris. A truly great discovery
Very pretty and relaxing church
Very welcoming, we participated in the mass in Spanish. The priest very friendly and made us feel like family.
